definitions: thin crisp biscuit typically made from flour and water
small explosive device that produces a loud noise when ignited
person who breaks into computer systems without authorization
examples: She served cheese and crackers at the party
The whole grain crackers tasted better than expected
Children set off firecrackers during the festival celebrations
The loud cracker startled everyone in the quiet room
Security experts tracked the cracker through digital footprints
The cracker bypassed several layers of network security

definitions: process or sound of something breaking or splitting apart with sharp noise
industrial process that breaks down large hydrocarbon molecules into smaller ones
examples: The cracking of ice warned them of danger ahead
She heard the cracking of branches under his feet
Thermal cracking produces gasoline from heavier oil fractions
The refinery specializes in catalytic cracking of petroleum

definitions: rapid succession of short sharp sounds like breaking twigs
network of fine cracks in glaze or varnish on pottery or paintings
examples: The fire's crackle filled the quiet cabin warmly
Static crackle interrupted the radio broadcast several times
The antique vase showed beautiful crackle in its glaze
Deliberate crackle gives this pottery its distinctive appearance

definitions: crispy rendered skin of roasted pork served as food
continuous series of short sharp cracking sounds
examples: The roast pork had perfect golden crackling on top
She bought crackling from the butcher for Sunday dinner
The crackling of the campfire created a cozy atmosphere
Electric crackling warned of the approaching thunderstorm

definitions: small bed for infant that can be rocked from side to side
framework or structure that holds and supports something during work or transport
place where something originates or develops in its early stages
examples: The antique wooden cradle had been in the family for generations
She gently rocked the cradle to soothe the crying baby
The ship rested in its cradle during the repairs
Workers used a window cleaner's cradle to reach high floors
Ancient Mesopotamia is considered the cradle of civilization
Silicon Valley became the cradle of technological innovation

definitions: activity involving skill in making things by hand
boat, aircraft, or spacecraft designed for specific purpose
skill in deceiving others or achieving goals through clever means
examples: She learned the craft of pottery from her grandmother
Traditional craft techniques are preserved by local artisans
The small craft navigated through the narrow channel carefully
Several pleasure craft were moored in the harbor
His political craft helped him navigate complex negotiations
The spy used considerable craft to obtain the information

definitions: worker skilled in particular craft requiring manual dexterity and artistic ability
examples: The master craftsman taught apprentices traditional woodworking techniques
Local craftsmen created all the church's ornate decorations
Each piece showed the craftsman's attention to detail
The furniture craftsman specialized in restoration of antiques

definitions: quality of design and work shown in something made by hand with skill
examples: The violin displayed exceptional craftsmanship in every detail
Fine craftsmanship distinguishes handmade furniture from mass production
Years of training developed her superb craftsmanship in jewelry
The building's craftsmanship reflects nineteenth century construction methods

definitions: steep rugged rock or cliff projecting from a mountain or hillside
examples: Eagles nested on the highest crag overlooking the valley
Climbers carefully navigated the dangerous crag near the summit
The castle stood atop a formidable crag above the river
Mist swirled around the crag in the early morning

definitions: painful involuntary contraction of muscle often caused by fatigue or strain
metal bar with bent ends for holding masonry or timber together
examples: The runner stopped suddenly with a severe leg cramp
Swimming too soon after eating can cause stomach cramps
The carpenter used cramps to hold the glued boards together
Stone cramps secured the blocks in the ancient wall

definitions: small acid red berry used in cooking and juice production
examples: Fresh cranberry sauce accompanied the traditional turkey dinner
She drank cranberry juice daily for its health benefits
The bog produced thousands of pounds of cranberries annually
Dried cranberries added sweetness to the salad

definitions: large long-necked wading bird found in wetlands worldwide
tall machine for moving heavy objects by suspending them from projecting arm
act of stretching one's neck to see something better
examples: The sandhill crane stood motionless in the shallow water
Migrating cranes flew overhead in perfect formation
The construction crane lifted steel beams to the top floor
A mobile crane removed the damaged truck from the highway
Everyone had to crane their necks to see the parade
She craned forward to hear the quiet conversation

definitions: bony structure of the skull that encloses and protects the brain
examples: The fossil's cranium showed evidence of early human evolution
Surgeons carefully examined the fracture in his cranium
The cranium consists of eight bones fused together
Brain size can be estimated from cranium measurements

definitions: handle or arm attached at right angles to rotating shaft for conversion of motion
person with strange ideas or eccentric behavior considered annoying by others
irritable or bad-tempered state of mind
examples: He turned the crank to start the old car engine
The window opened smoothly with the hand crank
The neighborhood crank complained about everything constantly
Don't mind him, he's just an old crank
She woke up in a crank mood after little sleep
The heat made everyone crank and irritable

definitions: solid waste matter from the body; excrement
nonsensical or false statements and ideas
things of extremely poor quality or little value
examples: The dog left crap all over the yard again
Bird crap covered the car's windshield completely
Don't believe that crap about instant weight loss
He talks complete crap when he's nervous
Clear all that crap out of the garage immediately
The store sells nothing but cheap crap

definitions: violent collision of vehicle or aircraft causing damage
loud sound of something breaking or colliding violently
sudden failure of computer system or program to function
sudden severe downturn in financial market or economic conditions
examples: The car crash blocked traffic for several hours
Three people survived the plane crash miraculously
The crash of thunder woke everyone in the house
We heard the crash of dishes from the kitchen
A software crash lost all my unsaved work
The server crash affected thousands of users worldwide
The stock market crash wiped out millions in value
The housing crash left many homeowners underwater

definitions: large wooden or plastic box used for transporting or storing goods
examples: Workers loaded heavy crates onto the cargo ship
The furniture arrived in several large wooden crates
Fresh vegetables were packed in plastic crates for transport
Old milk crates make excellent storage solutions

definitions: bowl-shaped cavity at the top of volcano or geyser
large cavity in ground or surface caused by explosion or impact
examples: Tourists peered into the volcano's smoking crater carefully
The crater lake formed inside the dormant volcano
The meteor left a massive crater in the desert
Bomb craters scarred the battlefield for decades

definitions: powerful desire for something, especially food, drink, or addictive substances
examples: Her pregnancy cravings included pickles and ice cream
The craving for nicotine made quitting difficult
He fought his craving for sweets during the diet
Sudden cravings often indicate nutritional deficiencies

definitions: small freshwater crustacean resembling lobster found in rivers and streams
examples: Louisiana crawfish boils are popular social gatherings
The crawfish hid under rocks in the shallow stream
Fresh crawfish season runs from March through June
They caught crawfish using simple wire traps

definitions: slow movement on hands and knees or with body close to ground
swimming stroke with alternating overarm movements and flutter kick
examples: The baby's first crawl across the room excited everyone
Traffic moved at a crawl during rush hour
She swam the crawl faster than any other stroke
The front crawl is taught first in swimming lessons

definitions: creature that moves by crawling, especially insects or babies
computer program that systematically browses web for indexing purposes
examples: The garden was full of crawlers after the rain
Baby crawlers need safe spaces to explore freely
Search engine crawlers index billions of web pages daily
The web crawler detected changes to the site immediately

definitions: act of moving slowly on hands and knees or with body close to ground
examples: The crawling phase helps babies develop motor skills
Crawling through the tunnel required patience and courage
Insects were crawling all over the picnic blanket
The soldier practiced crawling under barbed wire

definitions: small lobster-like freshwater crustacean found in streams and lakes
examples: The clear stream contained numerous crayfish under rocks
Crayfish are important indicators of water quality
Children caught crayfish with nets in the creek
The restaurant served crayfish as a seasonal delicacy

definitions: stick of colored wax or chalk used for drawing and coloring
examples: The child drew a rainbow with bright crayons
Melted crayons created interesting art projects
She bought a new box of sixty-four crayons
Restaurant crayons kept children entertained while waiting

definitions: temporary enthusiasm for something shared by many people
network of fine cracks on surface of glaze or paint
examples: The fitness craze swept through the entire country
Social media creates new crazes almost weekly
Age created a craze pattern in the painting's varnish
The pottery's craze added to its antique character

definitions: person who behaves in wild, unpredictable, or mentally unstable manner
person extremely enthusiastic about particular activity or interest
examples: The old crazy shouted at imaginary enemies constantly
Local crazies gathered at the conspiracy theory meeting
She's a fitness crazy who exercises twice daily
Golf crazies spend fortunes on equipment

definitions: thick white or pale yellow fatty liquid from milk
thick liquid or semi-solid cosmetic or medical preparation for skin
best or choicest part of something
examples: She poured fresh cream into her morning coffee
Whipped cream topped the chocolate dessert perfectly
Apply the medicinal cream twice daily for best results
Her face cream contained natural moisturizing ingredients
Only the cream of applicants received job interviews
The cream of society attended the charity gala

definitions: powdered or liquid non-dairy substitute for cream in coffee or tea
small pitcher or container for serving cream
examples: She preferred powdered creamer in her office coffee
Non-dairy creamer lasts longer than real cream
The silver creamer matched the sugar bowl perfectly
Grandmother's china creamer held special memories

definitions: establishment where butter and cheese are made from milk and cream
examples: The local creamery produced award-winning artisan cheeses
Tours of the creamery showed traditional butter-making methods
The old creamery building was converted into apartments
Fresh milk arrived at the creamery every morning

definitions: line or ridge produced on paper or fabric by folding or pressing
examples: Iron out the creases in your shirt before wearing
The letter's crease showed where it had been folded
Sharp creases in his trousers showed military precision
Years of folding left permanent creases in the map

definitions: organic compound supplying energy to muscle cells, often used as dietary supplement for athletic performance
examples: Athletes take creatine supplements to improve muscle strength
Natural creatine levels decrease with age
The study examined creatine's effects on exercise performance
Red meat contains high levels of natural creatine

definitions: action or process of bringing something into existence
thing that has been made or invented, especially something artistic
divine act of bringing the universe or life into existence
examples: The creation of the sculpture took six months
Job creation remains a top government priority
Her latest creation won first prize at the fair
The chef's dessert creation amazed all the guests
Many religions describe creation in their sacred texts
The museum's creation exhibit explores different cultural beliefs

definitions: belief that universe and living organisms originate from specific acts of divine creation rather than natural processes
examples: Creationism conflicts with scientific theories of evolution
Schools debated whether to teach creationism alongside evolution
Different forms of creationism exist across various religions
Young earth creationism claims the world is only thousands of years old

definitions: ability to use imagination to produce original ideas or things, especially in artistic work
examples: Children's natural creativity flourishes in supportive environments
The project required both technical skill and creativity
Her creativity in solving problems impressed the team
Artistic creativity often emerges from personal struggles

definitions: person who brings something into existence, especially artistic or intellectual work
God or divine being believed to have created the universe
examples: The creator of the series won multiple awards
Content creators share their work on social media
Many believe the Creator designed everything with purpose
Prayers thanked the Creator for life's blessings

definitions: any living thing, especially a non-human animal
person of specified type, often suggesting dependency or predictability
examples: Strange creatures inhabit the ocean's deepest trenches
The forest was home to many nocturnal creatures
She was a creature of habit who never changed routines
Poor creature, she never had a chance at happiness

definitions: belief in or acceptance of something as true, often without proof
examples: The jury gave little credence to his testimony
Scientific evidence lends credence to the theory
Don't give credence to unfounded rumors
Her expertise gave credence to the proposal

definitions: qualification, achievement, or aspect of background that indicates suitability for something
examples: Her academic credentials impressed the hiring committee
Security checked everyone's credentials at the entrance
The doctor's credentials were displayed on the office wall
Strong credentials don't guarantee job performance

definitions: quality of being trusted and believed in, based on reliability and competence
examples: The scandal destroyed his credibility as a leader
Scientific journals maintain credibility through peer review
Her years of experience gave her credibility with clients
The witness's credibility came under intense scrutiny

definitions: ability to borrow money or purchase goods with promise of future payment
public acknowledgment or praise for achievement or contribution
entry recording sum received in financial account
examples: Her excellent credit allowed her to buy the house
The store offered six months of interest-free credit
The director gave credit to the entire production team
She deserves credit for the project's success
The accountant recorded a credit in the client's account
Tax credits reduced their overall payment significantly

definitions: person or institution to whom money is owed
examples: Creditors demanded immediate payment of outstanding debts
The bankruptcy left many creditors with losses
Banks are the largest creditors in most economies
She negotiated with creditors to restructure the debt

definitions: statement of beliefs or aims that guides someone's actions
examples: Her personal credo emphasized honesty above all else
The company's credo hung prominently in the lobby
His artistic credo rejected all forms of commercialism
The warrior's credo demanded absolute loyalty

definitions: formal statement of religious beliefs or confession of faith
system of beliefs or principles that guide behavior
examples: The Nicene Creed is recited in many Christian churches
Different creeds exist within the same religion
Their family creed emphasized education and hard work
The organization operated by a simple creed of service

definitions: small stream or minor tributary of a river
examples: Children played in the shallow creek behind their house
The creek dried up during the summer drought
Trout fishing in the mountain creek proved successful
They followed the creek until it joined the river

definitions: person who behaves in an unpleasant way that makes others uncomfortable
slow, careful movement to avoid detection
examples: That creep kept staring at everyone on the train
Don't be such a creep at the party
The cat's silent creep toward the bird went unnoticed
Mission creep expanded the project beyond original goals

definitions: plant that grows along the ground or climbs walls and trees
one-piece garment for babies that covers torso and snaps at crotch
examples: Virginia creeper covered the old brick wall completely
The creeper's tendrils wrapped around the garden fence
She dressed the baby in a warm fleece creeper
The creeper made diaper changes much easier

definitions: slow gradual movement or development that is barely noticeable
examples: The creeping inflation worried economic analysts
Creeping doubt began to undermine his confidence
Urban development showed creeping expansion into farmland
The creeping fog obscured visibility on the highway

definitions: disposal of dead body by burning it to ashes
examples: The family chose cremation over traditional burial
Hindu cremation ceremonies take place along the Ganges
Cremation costs less than traditional funeral services
Environmental concerns have increased cremation's popularity

definitions: building where dead bodies are cremated
examples: The crematorium handled services for three funeral homes
A memorial garden surrounded the modern crematorium
The crematorium's furnaces operated at extremely high temperatures
They held a small ceremony at the crematorium
